question_text: Two equal bulbs, one containing ammonia and the other nitrogen are opened mouth-to-mouth to each other at room temperature. The entropy in the mixture of gases is likely to
subject: chemistry
explanation: In order to predict the sign of \(\Delta S\), let's consider some of the factors that obviously affect the entropy of a system: addition or removal of heat, addition of energy to the system, change of state and so on. We know, for instance, that if you increase temperature, you increase entropy. Heat is not added to the system. Same thing with other forms of energy. Also, we are not dealing with a solid changing to a liquid or a liquid to gas and so on. In the case of a liquid changing to a gas, for example, it would be easy to predict that the entropy will increase and \(\Delta S > 0\).Unfortunately, predicting the change in entropy for this system requires some other considerations. In the physical process, two different gases are allowed to mix with one another. We know that nitrogen is heavier than ammonia. We also know that with regards to atomic substances, heavier atoms possess greater entropy at a given temperature than lighter atoms (explaining why this is so will require delving into quantum mechanics). Based on this, we could conclude that the mixture will result in an increase in the entropy of the system.We could also take a molecular-scale statistical approach and observe the microstates of this system. Recall that a microstate is a specific way in which we can arrange the energy of the system. Check out this lesson to see some visual models and examples. There are more possible microstates associated with an even distribution of the ammonia and nitrogen particles between the two bulbs than there are microstates in which the gas particles remain in their respective bulbs. And one of the former microstates is the most probable configuration for the system. Besides, the random motion of gas particles is a spontaneous process. Entropy increases logarithmically with the number of microstates.In addition, thanks to the second law of thermodynamics, we know that the entropy of the final mixture has to be equal to or greater than the initially isolated systems. Equality occurs just when the two original systems have all their respective intensive variables (temperature, pressure) equal; then the final system also has the same values. If we were dealing with two identical gases, then the answer would have been that the entropy will remain unchanged.
